possible_responses: number of students on the course
data.stimulus:
Understanding Data

 

In your Market Report, your research must find and present data to help the audience to understand your course and the international student market.

 

► Here is some useful vocabulary to talk about data:
data.template:
1. {{response}} - an element or feature that can be different or change.
  2. {{response}} - same as "numeric" variables, these represent factors which can be measured or counted.
    Some examples are "{{response}}" or "{{response}}".
  3. {{response}} - same as "categorical" variables. These represent qualities that cannot be counted.
    They belong to a group or category, for example "{{response}}" or "{{response}}".
  4. {{response}} - the process of selecting relevant information from a range of sources to use in your report.

Adapted from: Statology (2020). Qualitative vs. Quantitative Variables: What's the Difference? https://www.statology.org/qualitative-vs-quantitative-variables/

options.label: Where do international students live whilst they study?
How much do students spend on their accommodation?
What is their overall opinion of where they live?
What area of Australia do students live in?

Using your SWOT table

After completing your SWOT table, you need to put the factors into paragraph form in your report.
data.template:
► This is called the 'write-up' stage.

What do the words in GREEN mean? Choose from the drop down.

 

The ‘write-up’ stage is when you choose the most significant ({{response}}) data to illustrate ({{response}}) the findings of your research.

You will NOT use all of information in the ‘write-up’: your task is to prioritise ({{response}}) the most useful factors.

data.stimulus:
Step #3: Write Your Paragraphs

After completing your SWOT table and prioritising the most important factors, it's time to write your paragraphs.

 

► REMBEMBER

  • One paragraph for each part of your SWOT = four paragraphs
  • Start with a clear topic sentence.
  • Use evidence to support your claims.
  • Signpost your ideas to help organise them.
     
Read the example SWOT paragraph below and label it by choosing an option from the drop-down.

Topic Sentences

► Each paragraph in your SWOT write-up needs a CLEAR TOPIC SENTENCE which gives the main and supporting ideas of that section.

 

Do you want to recap Topic Sentences?
► Review the lessons Mastering Academic Reports 1 and 2 in the Fashion Module! 

 

 

 

Order the words and phrases below into a correct topic sentence.

value: Research from outside of an organisation
to carefully select useful information from a large set of data
The main idea that connects supporting points
to show something to help the audience understand your point

to carefully select useful information from a large set of data

Finally, we will look at the last part of your secondary research section...

Key Drivers

In this part of your secondary research section, you need to present the research findings which help the audience understand the reasons why students choose to study abroad.

► In this report, these reasons are called 'Key Drivers'.

 

 

Here is some useful vocabulary for this part.

► Match each word to the correct definition.

to carefully select useful information from a large set of data
The main idea that connects supporting points
to show something to help the audience understand your point

Here are some KEY DRIVERS

► Remember: key drivers are reasons why International students might want to study abroad

 

Read the KEY DRIVERS below and decide which THEME they belong to.

► Are they economic, cultural, educational or social reasons?

 

  • Here is an example: 
  • Reputation of the qualification ⇒ this is an educational DRIVER because it is related to what the student will study.

Vocabulary: Changes over time.

► You will need to use appropriate language to describe your findings.

 

Here is some useful vocabulary to present changes over time.

value: Figure 1: Educational Drivers for International Students Studying in Australia from 2010-2020 (QILT, 2021)

data.stimulus:
Writing your 'Key Drivers' Paragraph

Below is an example extract from a report.

This extract is structured and looks the same as your paragraphs.
 

Read the extract and choose the best option from the drop-down to complete the text.
data.template:
{{response}}

{{response}}

Figure 1 shows the educational driver results of the Australia Student Experience Survey between 2010 and 2020 (QILT, 2021). In 2020, all three reasons were equally important to international students. However, in 2010 the results varied dramatically. Only around 75% of those surveyed chose ‘Institution offered the course I wanted to study’ as a reason for studying in Australia. This number {{response}} each year and {{response}} a peak (96%) in 2020. In addition, results show that ‘quality of teaching’ has become a much bigger priority since 2014 when only 88% of students selected it as important (compared to 96% in 2010 and 92% in 2020). Finally, the importance of the qualification’s reputation has {{response}} steady since 2010 and a large majority (96%) of respondents stated it was important in 2020.

value: Figure 1: Educational Drivers for International Students Studying in Australia from 2010-2020 (QILT, 2021)
